sections.text:
The Tibetan medicine ‘LuRu’ have a wide range of ethnopharmacological uses.
The common ‘LuRu’ varieties are P. flava and P. muscicola. The volatile components
were qualitative and semi-quantitative analysis by GC-MS. A total of 46 compounds from volatile components of P. flava and P. muscicola were identified. The
compounds mainly contain terpenoids, fatty acids, alkanes and other compounds. The non-volatile components were qualitative and semi-quantitative analysis by UHPLC-
Q-TOF-MS. A total of 68 compounds were identified from non-volatile components of P. flava and P. muscicola. The compounds mainly contain iridoids, flavonoids,
lignans, phenylpropanoid glycosides, organic acids, alkaloids and other compounds. Both‘LuRu’ stemed from P. flava or P. muscicola are significant differences in volatile and non-volatile components, so the two herbs can’t be mixed or substituted in clinical medication. The P. flava can represent the efficacy of Tibetan medicine
‘LuRu’. 1. Experimental 1.1 Materials and chemicals
P. flava and P. muscicola were come from Lhasa, Tibet, China. The P. flava were
collected on 19 May 2020 and the P. muscicola on 18 March 2020, respectively. P. flava and P. muscicola were identified to The Jiangxi University of Chinese Medicine
resource identification expert Guoyue ZHONG. The specimens P. flava (NO.20210519) and P. muscicola (NO.20210318) were deposited in the National
Engineering Research Center for Manufacturing Technology of solid preparations of Chinese Jiangxi University of Chinese Medicine. The reference standards of cinnamic
acid, loganic acid, homogentisic acid, acteoside, luteolin, and quercetin were purchased from were purchased from National Institutes for Food and Drug Control
(Beijing, China). Methanol and acetonitrile of HPLC grade were purchased from Fisher Scientific (Fair Lawn, NJ, USA). Formic acid of HPLC grade was obtained
from SIGMA Aldrich (St. Louis, USA). Distilled Water (A.S. Watson Group). All
other chemicals and reagents were of HPLC grade. GraphPad Prism 8. 1.2 Preparation of samples 1.2.1 Sample preparation for volatile component analysis
The volatile components of P. flava or P. muscicola were extracted by steam
distillation in duplicates for 6 h (300 g in 3 L tap water). Cyclohexane was dissolved
in essential oil (EO), then the volatile oil was collected in a graduated tube, dried over anhydrous sodium sulphate, and stored at 4 °C for further use.
1.2.2 Sample preparation for non-volatile component analysis
Precisely weigh 1g of P. flava (or P. muscicola) powder, put it in a 50 ml conical
flask, add 10 ml of methanol, weigh and ultrasonicate for 30 min, take it out and let it cool, weigh it, make up for the loss with methanol, shake well, and filter it through a
0.22 μm microporous filter. Membrane filtration, take the continuous filtrate. 1.3 GC–MS analysis condition
GC-MS analysis was performed to characterise the volatile composition of P.
flava and P. muscicola. Agilent benchtop GC-MS (Agilent Technologies, Wilmington, DE, USA) equipment with a capillary column of HP-5MS (60 m length, 0.25 mm i.d.,
0.25 μm film thickness) was used for the test sample analysis. Argon was used as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The oven temperature was programmed as
follows: 50 °C for 3 min, 130 °C at 5 °C/min, 200 °C at 10 °C/min, 200 °C for 2 min, 300 °C at 5 °C/min, and 300 °C for 10 min, resulting in a total run time of 58 min.
The injected sample volume was 1 μL with a split ratio of 10:1. GC-MS data were captured at 70 eV using scanning times of 1.5 sec in the mass range of 50–550 m/z.
Further identification of essential oil constituents was performed by comparing the fragmentation patterns of mass spectra obtained by GC/MS analysis with those stored
in the NIST17.L library and calculating the relative mass fraction of each component by peak area normalization. Relative percentage amounts of the separated compounds
were calculated from total ion chromatograms by the computerized integrator. 1.4 UPLC-Q-TOF-MS analysis condition
UPLC-Q-TOF-MS analysis was performed to characterise the non-volatile
composition of P. flava and P. muscicola. Liquid chromatographic analysis was performed using Nexera UPLC LC-30A instrument. The sample was separated on
Welch Ultimate® UHPLC XB-C18 (3×100 mm, 1.8 μm) at 40 °C. The mobile phase consisted of water, 0.1 % formic acid (A), and acetonitrile (B). A gradient elution was
programmed as follows: 0.01–5 min, 5–8 % B; 5–12 min, 8–12 % B; 12–30 min, 12– 20 % B; 30–35 min, 20–35 % B, 35–38 min, 35–50 % B; 38–40 min, and 50–95 % B.
The flow rate and the injection volume were set at 0.3 mL/min and 3 uL, respectively.
The UPLC system was coupled to a Triple TOF TM 5600 (AB SCIEX, Foster
City, Canada) equipped with an electrospray ionisation (ESI) source. Q-TOF-MS analysis was performed in both positive and negative ion modes in the full scan mode.
The optimised MS parameters were set as follows: ion spray voltage (ISV): 5500 V (ESI+) or −4500 V (ESI−); ion source temperature (TEM): 550 °C or 450 ℃; ion
source gas 1 (GS1): 60 psi; ion source gas 2 (GS2): 50 psi; curtain gas (CUR): 40 psi; declustering potential (DP): 100 V; collision energy (CE): 40/−40 eV (MS mode);
collision energy spread (CES): 15 eV; scan range of TOF-MS; and product ion: m/z 50–1250 Da. Moreover, to ensure accurate mass measurements during the MS
experiments, the Triple TOFTM system was calibrated every 2 h in positive/negative mode using APCI-positive/negative calibration solutions supplied by AB SCIEX. All
data were collected and analysed using Analyst TF 1.6 (version 1.0; AB SCIEX, Foster City, CA), Peak View ® 1.6 (AB SCIEX, Foster City, Canada), and Master
View 1.0 softwares (AB SCIEX, Foster City, CA). Structures and fragmentation pathways were generated using Chemdraw 18.1 (Perkin-Elemer, USA).

Figure S2: GC-MS Chromatograms of P. muscicola
Figure S3: UPLC/Q-TOF-MS/MS total ion flow chart A (+) and B (-) of P. flava
Figure S4: UPLC/Q-TOF-MS/MS total ion flow chart A (+) and B (-) of P. muscicola
Fig S5: The venny maps and heat maps of Pedicularis flava
Fig S6: The venny maps and heat maps of Pedicularis muscicola
